overview: Ancient religious movement emphasizing gnosis (esoteric knowledge) as the path to salvation, viewing the material world as flawed and created by a lesser demiurge, with humans containing a divine spark that can be awakened for liberation from earthly bondage.
historical_context: Gnosticism emerged in the 1st-2nd centuries AD, influenced by Jewish, Christian, Hellenistic, and Platonic thought, flourishing in the Mediterranean region. Denounced as heresy by early Church Fathers like Irenaeus, it was largely suppressed by the 4th century, with texts destroyed. Rediscovered through the Nag Hammadi library in 1945, revealing diverse sects like Sethians and Valentinians. Influences persisted in medieval groups like Cathars and Bogomils, and modern revivals in esoteric traditions.

core_principles.name: Gnosis as Salvation
core_principles.description: Esoteric knowledge (gnosis) awakens the divine spark within, leading to spiritual liberation beyond faith or rituals. This principle emphasizes direct, experiential knowledge of the divine rather than belief or adherence to external authority. Gnosis is understood as an inner illumination that reveals the true nature of reality and the practitioner's divine origin, providing the key to escape from the material prison of existence.
practical_applications: Contemplative meditation to access inner divine knowledge
Study of sacred texts for hidden meanings and revelations
Initiation ceremonies that impart esoteric wisdom
Personal revelation practices to awaken spiritual insight

core_principles.name: Dualism and the Demiurge
core_principles.description: Fundamental contrast between the transcendent, good spiritual realm (pleroma) and the flawed, evil material world created by the demiurge (Yaldabaoth). The demiurge is portrayed as a lesser, ignorant deity who fashioned the imperfect cosmos, often depicted as malevolent or blind to the true divine realm. This creates a cosmic struggle between spiritual liberation and material entrapment.
practical_applications: Recognition of material world as illusion to be transcended
Resistance to worldly authorities and orthodox religious institutions
Practices aimed at overcoming bodily limitations and desires
Cultivation of spiritual discernment between true and false teachings

core_principles.name: Divine Spark and Pleroma
core_principles.description: Humans contain a fragment of the divine pleroma (fullness), trapped in matter but seeking return through enlightenment. The divine spark represents the authentic self that originates from the supreme Monad and the realm of aeons. This spark is the basis for salvation and the means by which individuals can transcend the material world and reunite with their divine source.
practical_applications: Inner work to awaken and nurture the divine spark
Recognition of one's true spiritual identity beyond material existence
Practices to connect with the pleroma through meditation and ritual
Development of pneumatic (spiritual) consciousness over psychic and material awareness

core_principles.name: Rejection of Orthodox Authority
core_principles.description: Emphasis on personal insight over institutional dogma, viewing orthodox scriptures as corrupted or incomplete. Gnostics maintained that true spiritual authority comes from direct revelation and gnosis rather than ecclesiastical hierarchy or canonical texts. This principle led to the development of alternative gospels and teachings that challenged mainstream religious authority.
practical_applications: Critical examination of religious texts for hidden or suppressed meanings
Development of personal spiritual practices independent of institutional guidance
Creation and preservation of alternative sacred literature
Formation of esoteric communities based on shared gnosis rather than orthodox doctrine

practices.name: Baptism and Purification Rites
practices.description: Repeated immersions in living water for soul purification and gnosis awakening, often performed multiple times to cleanse the divine spark of material contamination.
instructions: Prepare sacred space with flowing or 'living' water
Enter water with intention of spiritual purification
Perform multiple immersions while contemplating divine nature
Emerge with renewed commitment to gnostic path
warnings: Should be performed with proper guidance

practices.name: Bridal Chamber Rite
practices.description: Mystical union ritual symbolizing the soul's marriage to the divine, representing the ultimate goal of gnostic practice - reunion with the pleroma.
instructions: Create sacred chamber space representing the pleroma
Engage in contemplative preparation and purification
Perform symbolic union ceremony with divine counterpart
Experience mystical marriage and spiritual transformation

practices.name: Meditation on Divine Names and Passwords
practices.description: Contemplative practices using sacred names and passwords believed necessary for the soul's ascent through the archonic spheres after death.
instructions: Study the names and attributes of aeons and archons
Memorize passwords for passage through each sphere
Engage in regular meditation on divine emanations
warnings: Requires accurate knowledge of traditional teachings
Should be learned from authentic sources

notable_figures.name: Valentinus
notable_figures.contribution: Founder of Valentinianism; integrated Christian elements with gnostic cosmology, nearly elected bishop of Rome.

notable_figures.name: Basilides
notable_figures.contribution: Alexandrian teacher who developed a unique system blending philosophy and gnosis.

notable_figures.name: Mani
notable_figures.contribution: Founder of Manichaeism, a dualistic gnostic religion blending Zoroastrian, Christian, and Buddhist elements.

notable_figures.name: Simon Magus
notable_figures.contribution: Early figure accused of heresy; legendary founder of Simonianism, emphasizing divine thought.

notable_figures.name: Elaine Pagels
notable_figures.contribution: Modern scholar; authored The Gnostic Gospels, popularizing Nag Hammadi texts.

notable_figures.name: Stephan A. Hoeller
notable_figures.contribution: Gnostic bishop and author; founded Ecclesia Gnostica, reviving gnostic practices.
